question: Ne man ne (sculan) #### drincan oððe etan binnan Godes huse — No man shall drink or eat within God's house
explanation: Here 'sculan' is in the third person present and modifying 'drican' so it becomes 'sceal'

question: Mæssepreost (sculan) #### habban mæsseboc — A mass-priest shall have a mass-book
explanation: Here 'sculan' is in the third person present and modifying 'habban' so it becomes 'sceal'

question: Hie (sculan) #### gehiran hwæt Paulus cwæð — They should listen to what Paul said
explanation: Here 'sculan' is in the plural past and modifying 'gehiran' so it becomes 'scoldon'

question: Þus wæs gewriten be me: þæt ic þrowian (sculan) #### and arisan of deaðe on ðam þriddan dæge — This was decreed about me: that I should suffer, and arise from death on the third day
explanation: Here 'sculan' is in the first person past and modifying 'þrowian' so it becomes 'scolde'

question: Ða axode heo hine hwæðer heo (sculan) #### þa næglæs mid hire læden — Then she asked him whether she should carry the nails with her
explanation: Here 'sculan' is in the third person past and modifying 'læden' so it becomes 'scolde'

question: Nu we (sculan) #### herian heofonrices weard — Now we shall praise the guardian of the kingdom of heaven
explanation: Here 'sculan' is in the plural past and modifying 'herian' so it becomes 'sculon'

question: Hu (magan) #### blind man oðerne lædan? — How may a blind man lead another?
explanation: Here 'magan' is in the third person present and modifying 'lædan' so it becomes 'mæg'

question: Witodlice ic (magan) #### ma secgan — Truly I may say more
explanation: Here 'magan' is in the first person present and modifying 'secgan' so it becomes 'mæg'

question: Swa feor swa he (magan) #### on þrim dagum gesiglan — As far as he might sail in three days
explanation: Here 'magan' is in the third person past and modifying 'gesiglan' so it becomes 'meahte'

question: Heo þone þeow findan ne (magan) #### — She couldn't find the servant
explanation: Here 'magan' is in the third person past and modifying 'findan' so it becomes 'meahte'

question: Peter, forhwon ne (magan) #### þu ane tid wacian mid me? — Peter, why could you not watch with me for an hour?
explanation: Here 'magan' is in the second person past and modifying 'wacian' so it becomes 'meahtest'

question: Fela þinga we (magan) #### writan — We can write about many things
explanation: Here 'magan' is in the plural present and modifying 'writan' so it becomes 'magon'

question: Sprec us æfter urum andgyte, þæt we (magan) #### understandan þa þing þe þu specst — Speak to us according to our knowledge, so that we may understand those things of which you speak
explanation: Here 'magan' is in the plural present and modifying 'understandan' so it becomes 'magon'

question: Hie ne (magan) #### þa wealas flieman — They could not expel the foreigners
explanation: Here 'magan' is in the plural past and modifying 'flieman' so it becomes 'meahton'

question: Hie þohton hu hie hine acwellan (magan) #### — They thought how they might kill him
explanation: Here 'magan' is in the plural past and modifying 'acwellan' so it becomes 'meahton'

question: Ic eode to minan abbode Ælfwine and bead hine þæt ic (motan) #### norþ faran — I went to my abbot Alfwin and told him that I must travel north
explanation: Here 'motan' is in the first person singular past and modifying 'faran' so it becomes 'moste'

question: Þa wearð seo cwen gegladod, þæt heo (motan) #### ðone maðm on moldan findan — Then the queen became gladened that she was able to find the treasure in the ground
explanation: Here 'motan' is in the third person singular past and modifying 'findan' so it becomes 'moste'

question: Ic restan ne (motan) #### — I am not able to rest
explanation: Here 'motan' is in the first person singular present and modifying 'restan' so it becomes 'mot'

question: Hwænne (motan) #### ic hine geseon? — When may I see him?
explanation: Here 'motan' is in the first person singular present and modifying 'geseon' so it becomes 'mot'

question: Þa hwile þe hi wæpna wealdan (motan) #### — As long as they can weild weapons
explanation: Here 'motan' is in the plural present and modifying 'wealdan' so it becomes 'moston'

question: Þæt we (motan) #### his willan gewyrcan ðurh sume weldæde — That we can work his will through some good deed
explanation: Here 'motan' is in the plural present and modifying 'gewyrcan' so it becomes 'moston'

question: Ic ne (cunnan) #### understandan — I cannot understand
explanation: Here 'cunnan' is in the first person present and modifying 'understandan' so it becomes 'can'

question: Ic (cunnan) #### eow læran — I can teach you
explanation: Here 'cunnan' is in the first person present and modifying 'læran' so it becomes 'can'

question: Hie dydon swa hie (cunnan) #### — They did as they could
explanation: Here 'cunnan' is in the plural past and modifying 'dydon' so it becomes 'cuþon'

question: Men ne (cunnan) #### secgan to soðe — Men could not say for sure
explanation: Here 'cunnan' is in the plural present and modifying 'secgan' so it becomes 'cunnon'

question: Þone soþan geleafan to (bodian) #### — In order to preach the true faith
explanation: Here 'bodian' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'bodienne'

question: Heo onfeng þæt land, mynster to (timbrian) #### — She siezed that land in order to build a monastery
explanation: Here 'timbrian' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'timbrienne'

question: Nys þe alyfed to (habban) #### þines broðer wif — It is not permitted to have your brother's wife
explanation: Here 'habban' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'hæbbenne'

question: Hie næfdon hlaf to (etan) #### — They didn't have bread to eat
explanation: Here 'etan' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'etenne'

question: Ut eode se sædere his sæd to (sawan) #### — Out went the farmer, in order to sow his seeds
explanation: Here 'sawan' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'sawenne'

question: Gehire gif hwa earan hæbbe to (hieran) #### — Hear, if one has ears to hear!
explanation: Here 'hieran' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'hierenne'

question: Eaþere ys olfende to (faran) #### þurh nædle þyrel þonne se rica on godes rice ga — It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for the rich to go to god's kingdom
explanation: Here 'faran' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'farenne'

question: Hie wilniað lof and wuldor to hæbbenne (habban) #### — They wished to have praise and glory
explanation: Here 'habban' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'hæbbenne'

question: He ferdon to Francrice, þæt land to (hergian) #### — They went to France in order to plunder that land
explanation: Here 'hergian' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'hergienne'

question: Heo ferde to circe, þæt godspell to (hieran) #### — She went to church to hear the gospel
explanation: Here 'hieran' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'hierenne'

question: Freolic to (libban) #### — In order to live free
explanation: Here 'libban' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'libbenne'

question: Werode to (helpan) #### on gefeohte — In order to help the people in battle
explanation: Here 'helpan' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'helpenne'

question: Wið fefre hylpþ wæter to (drincan) #### — Against fever it helps to drink water
explanation: Here 'drincan' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'drincenne'

question: Heo ferde to Eoferwice, þa wicingas to (helpan) #### — She went to York in order to help the vikings
explanation: Here 'helpan' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'helpenne'

question: Under þinum anwealde ic wilnie to (wunian) #### — Under your rule I should want to live
explanation: Here 'wunian' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'wunienne'

question: To helle gecuman to (helpan) #### Adames cyne — Come to Hell in order to help Adam's kin
explanation: Here 'helpan' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'helpenne'

question: Mæst þearf is to (gehealdan) #### rihtne cristendom — It is most necessary to keep correct christianity
explanation: Here 'gehealdan' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'gehealdenne'

question: Hie sealdon Ceolwulfe Myrcna rice to (healdan) #### — They gave Ceolwulf the kingdom of Mercia to hold
explanation: Here 'healdan' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'healdenne'

question: Þæt ðæt folc hæfð genoh to (drincan) #### — In order that that people have enough to drink
explanation: Here 'drincan' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'drincenne'

question: He ferde þa siþþan to (feohtan) #### wið þone casere — He went then afterwards in order to fight with the emperor
explanation: Here 'feohtan' loses the —an suffix and gains 'enne' to make the inflected infinitive 'feohtenne'

question: He wilnode þæt þæt folc wære (gecierran) #### to Criste — He always wished that that people might be converted to Christ
explanation: Here the verb 'cierran' is in the past tense and modifed by 'wære' so it becomes 'gecierred'

question: Com se Hælend on Galileam godspell (bodian) #### — The holy one came into Galilea, preaching the gospel
explanation: Here the verb 'bodian' is in the present tense and modifed by 'com' so it becomes 'bodiende'

question: Þa com he and fand hie (slæpan) ####, and cwæþ to Petre, 'Simon, slæpst þu?' — Then he came and found them sleeping, and said to Peter, 'Simon, do you sleep?'
explanation: Here the verb 'slæpan' is in the present tense and modifying the pronoun 'hie' so it becomes 'slæpende'

question: Se cyning hæfde þone mynster (getimbrian) #### — The king had built the monastery
explanation: Here the verb 'getimbrian' is in the past tense and modifed by 'hæfde' so it becomes 'getimbrod'

question: &AELIG;r ðæm ðe Rome (getimbrian) #### wære — Before Rome was built
explanation: Here the verb 'getimbrian' is in the past tense and modifed by 'wære' so it becomes 'getimbrod'

question: Sceal beon (gebodian) #### on minum naman forgifenyss — Forgiveness shall be preached in my name
explanation: Here the verb 'bodian' is in the past tense and modifed by 'beon' so it becomes 'gebodod'

question: Se feorða heafodricu is Romane, þe giet (ricsian) #### sindon — The fourth empire is Roman, which is yet reigning
explanation: Here the verb 'ricsian' is in the present tense and modifed by 'sindon' so it becomes 'ricsiende'

question: Þu eart (gelufian) #### — You are loved
explanation: Here the verb 'gelufian' is in the past tense and modifed by 'eart' so it becomes 'gelufod'

question: Apollonius ongeat þæt he (gelufian) #### wæs fram þæm mædene — Apollonius perceived that he was loved by that maiden
explanation: Here the verb 'gelufian' is in the past tense and modifed by 'wæs' so it becomes 'gelufod'

question: Þis (lufian) #### wif — This loving wife
explanation: Here the verb 'lufian' is in the present tense and modifying the noun 'wif' so it becomes 'lufiende'

question: Seo sawl bið (libban) #### — The soul is living
explanation: Here the verb 'libban' is in the present tense and modifed by 'bið' so it becomes 'libbende'

question: Ne miht ðu me geseon; ne syhð me nan (libban) #### man — You cannot see me; no living man sees me
explanation: Here the verb 'libban' is in the present tense and modifying the noun 'man' so it becomes 'libbiende'

question: Se halig abbod wæs fela wundra (wyrcan) #### — The holy abbot was working many wanders
explanation: Here the verb 'wyrcan' is in the present tense and modifed by 'wæs' so it becomes 'wyrcende'

question: God cwæð ða: Gewurðe leoht and leoht wæs (wyrcan) #### — God then said: 'Let there be light', and light was made.
explanation: Here the verb 'wyrcan' is in the past tense and modifed by 'wæs' so it becomes 'geworht'

question: Þær wæs þære sunnan anlycnys (wyrcan) #### of golde — There the sun's likeness was made from gold
explanation: Here the verb 'wyrcan' is in the past tense and modifed by 'wæs' so it becomes 'geworht'

question: Ic wunie on þæm (gehergian) #### lande — I live in the plundered land
explanation: Here the verb 'hergian' is in the past tense and modifying the noun 'land' so it becomes 'gehergodan'

question: Þa Deniscan leode ferdon mid sciphere (hergian) #### and sleande wide geond land — The Danish people travelled with a navy plundering and killing widely around the land
explanation: Here the verb 'hergian' is in the present tense and modified by 'ferdon' so it becomes 'hergiende'

question: Hie wæron (hergian) #### on Scotlande — They were plundering in Scotland
explanation: Here the verb 'hergian' is in the present tense and modified by 'wæron' so it becomes 'hergiende'

question: On þissum geare wæs Gypeswic (gehergian) #### — In this year, Ipswich was plundered
explanation: Here the verb 'hergian' is in the past tense and modified by 'wæs' so it becomes 'gehergod'

question: Ic eom (lufian() #### — I am loved
explanation: Here the verb 'lufod' is in the past tense and modified by 'eom' so it becomes 'gelufod'
